text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Updated IRM 4.24.14, Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform and Motor Vehicle Requirements.
Updated 4.24.14 material changes are listed below:

IRM Description 4.24.14.7.10 Strobe Lights Title changed to Designated In- spection Site Signs and Safety Cones. Guidance moved from 4.24.7.7.11. Prior guidance obsoleted. 4.24.14.7.11 Designated Inspec- tion Site Signs and Safety Cones Subsection deleted. Prior guidance moved to 4.24.14.7.10. 4.24.14.10 Motor Vehicle Use and Management Removed reference to AWSS, which is now FMSS. Added citations for regulations address- ing use of government vehicles. 4.24.14.10.1 Motor Vehicle Use - Group Manager Responsibilities Changed the title to FMSS Fleet Manager. 4.24.14.10.3 Use of Fleet Credit Card and Odometer Reading Re- quirements for Motor Vehicle Purchases Refreshed the electronic link to Important Fleet Publications at the GSA website. 4.24.14.10.3.1 Vehicle Mainte- nance and Repairs Noted that the operator is respon- sible to ensure the vehicle is properly maintained. 4.24.14.10.4 Use of E85 Fuel for Motor Vehicles Refreshed the electronic link to Alternative Fuel Data Center - Alternative Fueling Station Locations at the Department of Energy website. Added clariﬁca- tion regarding when a waiver is issued. 4.24.14.13 Vehicle Accident or Damage Reporting Added statement when SF-91 is required. New Exhibit 4.24.14-2 Added title Steps to Excess and Dispose of Fuel Sampling Equipment and Supplies. Flow chart illustrates steps and proce- dures to excess and dispose of fuel sampling equipment and supplies. Added description to comply with 508 compliance requirements.
Added statement when SF-91 is required.
Editorial changes have been made throughout this revision, which includes updated websites.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 4.24.14, dated May 30, 2018, is superseded.
AUDIENCE

This section provides detailed guidance for Supervisory Fuel Compliance Officers, Excise Group Managers (GMs), Fuel Compliance Officers (FCOs) and Fuel Compliance Agents (FCAs). Information in this section may also support coordination with SB/SE excise groups.
Wanda R. Griffin
Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements
Program Scope and Objectives
Steps to Excess and Dispose Fuel Sampling Equipment and Supplies
and (

) Purpose - This IRM provides directives, authorities and responsibilities for Fuel Compliance Program to: a. Promote a proactive safety and health culture that supports the IRS mission. b. Ensure that Fuel Compliance Officers/Fuel Compliance Agents (FCO/As) and managers comply with federal, state, and local regulations, as well as, IRS safety and health rules and policies, and laws. c. Prevent injuries, illnesses, and accidents involving FCO/As. d. Operate government leased motor vehicle for official government business per regulations. (

) Audience - The intended audience of this IRM includes the Chief, Estate & Gift/Excise Tax, Territory Managers (TMs), Group Managers (GMs), Fuel pliance Officers (FCOs) and Fuel Compliance Agents (FCAs). (
) Policy Owner - Director, Examination – Specialty Policy owns the policies contained herein. (
) Program Owner - Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to the fuel compliance program. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Other areas that are affected by these policies and procedures include Counsel, Disclosure, Facilities Management Security Services (FMSS) and the Excise Forensics Laboratory (EFL). (
) The Fuel Compliance Program started in June
, following passage of Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of
that became effective on January

Initially, the focus of the program was on the proper sale and use diesel fuel indelibly dyed in accordance with IRS regulations. In subsequent years, the Fuel Compliance Program adapted as the fuel industry changed. Fuel inspections now involve a broader range of taxable fuels, as well as native fuels. For compliance purposes, it is essential FCOs, FCAs, GMs and senior management officials understand and follow the technical guidance explained in this section. (
) Authority – Physical examinations are conducted under

Code of Federal Regulation (CFR) Medical Qualiﬁcation Determination, Subpart A – General, Subpart B – Medical Standards, Physical Requirements and Medical Evalua- tion Programs and Subpart C – Medical Examinations. (
CFR

requires that each employer is required to provide informa- tion to their “employees about the hazardous chemicals to which they are exposed by means of a hazard communication program, labels, other forms warning, safety data sheets, information and training.” (
) Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is responsible for the procedures and policies in this IRM. (
) Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for ensuring that the dures are accurate and updated regularly, as needed. Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle
page
Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14 page
Purpose - This IRM provides directives, authorities and responsibilities for the Fuel Compliance Program to:

a. Promote a proactive safety and health culture that supports the IRS mission. b. Ensure that Fuel Compliance Officers/Fuel Compliance Agents (FCO/As) and managers comply with federal, state, and local regulations, as well as, IRS safety and health rules and policies, and laws. c. Prevent injuries, illnesses, and accidents involving FCO/As. d. Operate government leased motor vehicle for official government business per regulations.
Program Manager, Excise Tax Policy is responsible for ensuring that the proce- dures are accurate and updated regularly, as needed.
) Chief, Specialty Exam, Estate and Gift (E&G)/Excise Tax is responsible for ensuring compliance with the procedures within this IRM. (
) Excise TMs are responsible for ensuring that the GMs are aware and adhere to the procedures in this IRM. (
) Excise GMs are responsible for ensuring their FCO/As have current copies this IRM and are adhering to the procedures in this IRM. (

) The FCOs and FCAs are responsible for following all guidance in this IRM, it pertains to fuel compliance safety, uniform, and motor vehicle requirements. The term “FCO/A” is used throughout this section and refers to both the and FCA positions. (

) The goal of this IRM is to provide guidance that will enable the FCO/A to properly conduct inspections in a safe environment, describe required PPE, mandatory attire and to provide guidance as it pertains to motor vehicle agement. Following this guidance will ensure the FCO/A’s safety and adherence to the motor vehicle requirements outlined in
, Facilities agement, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, and Treasury Directives
and

) The effectiveness of FCO/As and GMs following the procedures outlined in IRM is evaluated with the use of the following: • Incident/accident reports • Recurring Hazardous Communication Program (HCP) training and ﬁcations • Periodic sampling, packing and shipping training and certiﬁcations • Shar
oint employee mileage log data entry analysis • Annual motor vehicle operator training classes and certiﬁcations (
) Review - The GM conducts the following reviews: • Condition of the ﬂeet vehicle and use in an authorized manner • Mileage Log - standard and comprehensive • Work Planning Reviews (

) All information management systems that are utilized have safeguard measures in place which address all key components of Information Technol- ogy (IT) security to restrict access to sensitive data. (
) The following table contains the deﬁnitions of the terms utilized throughout IRM section. Terminology Deﬁnitions: E-
percent denatured ethanol fuel and
percent gasoline. Fuel Compliance Officer/Agent (FCO/A) This term refers to both fuel com- pliance officers (FCOs) and fuel compliance agents (FCAs).

Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14

All employers with hazardous chemicals in their workplaces must prepare and implement a written hazard communication program, and must ensure that all containers are labeled, employees are provided access to Safety Data Sheets (SDSs), and an effective training program is conducted for all potentially exposed employees.
Home-to-Work Transportation
Use of a motor vehicle between an FCO/A’s residence and place of employment qualiﬁes as trans
portation for an official purpose only when the Secretary of the Treasury determines that trans
portation between residence and various locations is required for performance of ﬁeld work, in ac
cordance with applicable regulations.
Personal Protective Equipment

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) refers to protective clothing, helmets, goggles, or other garments or equipment designed to protect the wearer’s body from injury or exposure. The hazards addressed by protective equipment include physical, elec
trical, heat, chemicals, biohazards, and airborne particu
late matter.

Terminology Deﬁnitions: Safety Data Sheet A Safety Data Sheet (SDS) is a document that contains informa- tion on the potential health effects of exposure to chemicals, or other potentially dangerous sub- stances, and on safe working procedures when handling chemical products. 4.24 Excise Tax

Word Acronym Safety Data Sheet SDS Single Entry Time Reporting SETR
Word Acronym Safety Data Sheet SDS Single Entry Time Reporting SETR (
) There are safety concerns inherent in locations where inspections are performed and taxable fuel samples are collected. (

) FCO/A safety and the safety of others in all locations where fuel inspections and examinations are performed should be the priority. Adhering to safety guidelines will signiﬁcantly improve the ability to maintain a safe and healthy work environment. (
) FCO/As are trained to understand that all taxable fuels are dangerous to touch, or ingest and that the vapors of all taxable fuels will ignite when exposed to an open ﬂame. (
) FCO/As are trained, equipped, and certiﬁed to safely sample and ship all taxable fuels. (
) FCO/As and GMs are responsible for implementing provisions contained in IRM

, Occupational Health and Safety Program. This includes identifying, preventing and reporting unsafe or unhealthy working conditions. Various internal systems exist to assist GMs in meeting the requirements of this IRM. See the Employee Resource Center (ERC) website at Environmental Health and Safety for further information. Hazard Program (
) The IRS established the FC HCP to comply with the Department of Labor, cupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Hazard Communication Standard (HCS),
CFR
, and Basic Program Elements for Federal Employee Occupational Safety and Health Programs and Related Matters, CFR
Excise Tax Policy coordinates the FC HCP. (

) The duties of the FC HCP coordinator or designee, include: a. Reviewing and updating the program as necessary. b. Maintaining a list of all hazardous chemicals that FCO/As may encounter while performing their duties. c. Updating the list when new chemicals are introduced to the fuel compli- ance operation. d. Obtaining and maintaining a copy of each SDS representing each substance on the hazardous chemical list. e. Ensuring that FCO/As receive initial training and recurring training on HCS, as required. f. Providing additional training whenever a new hazard is identiﬁed or intro- duced. g. Coordinating initial and biennial physical examinations of FCO/As and ensuring the examinations are completed timely. h. Maintaining an active liaison with the IRS FMSS HQ Environment, Health and Safety.

Reviewing and updating the program as necessary. Maintaining a list of all hazardous chemicals that FCO/As may encounter while performing their duties. Updating the list when new chemicals are introduced to the fuel compli

ance operation. Obtaining and maintaining a copy of each SDS representing each substance on the hazardous chemical list. Ensuring that FCO/As receive initial training and recurring training on the HCS, as required. Providing additional training whenever a new hazard is identiﬁed or intro

duced. Coordinating initial and biennial physical examinations of FCO/As and ensuring the examinations are completed timely. Maintaining an active liaison with the IRS FMSS HQ Environment, Health and Safety.

• The HCS and the written IRS FC HCP. • The safety and health program speciﬁc to ﬁeld compliance operations. • The chemical and physical properties of the hazardous materials in taxable fuels (gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene) and methods that be used to detect their presence or release. • The health hazards, including signs and symptoms of exposure to the taxable fuels. • Any medical condition known to be aggravated by exposure to the taxable fuels. • The procedures to mitigate the hazards associated with taxable fuels, e.g., care and required use of personal protective equipment (PPE), approved work practices or methods to ensure proper use and handling of taxable fuels, safe climbing techniques, bonding procedures and emergency procedures. • The required use of PPE. • How to read and interpret the information on labels and SDSs. • How to obtain additional hazard information. Data Sheets (
) An SDS contains information regarding the properties of a particular substance and includes instructions for the safe use and potential hazards associated with the substance. (

) FCO/As must carry the current SDS for each type of taxable fuel common to their area of operation, in their government vehicle. Common SDS sheets include, but are not limited to: • All grades of gasoline • Diesel fuel • Dyed diesel fuel • Kerosene • Dyed kerosene • Jet fuel • The dye used to dye diesel and kerosene (
) Current SDSs are available on the Fuel Compliance Shar
oint site and on the internet at the web sites for the major oil companies. (
) All FCO/As must demonstrate the proper sampling, packing and shipping niques contained in IRM
, Excise Fuel Compliance Inspection, Sampling and Shipping. FCO/As who successfully demonstrate the techniques

The HCS and the written IRS FC HCP. The safety and health program speciﬁc to ﬁeld compliance operations. The chemical and physical properties of the hazardous materials in taxable fuels (gasoline, diesel fuel, and kerosene) and methods that used to detect their presence or release. The health hazards, including signs and symptoms of exposure to the taxable fuels. Any medical condition known to be aggravated by exposure to the taxable fuels. The procedures to mitigate the hazards associated with taxable fuels, e.g., care and required use of personal protective equipment (PPE), approved work practices or methods to ensure proper use and handling taxable fuels, safe climbing techniques, bonding procedures and emergency procedures. The required use of PPE. How to read and interpret the information on labels and SDSs.
4.24.14.3.1(05-30-2018) Safety Data Sheets (SDS)
Current SDSs are available on the Fuel Compliance SharePoint site and on the internet at the web sites for the major oil companies.
e. Completing Form
, Sample Bottle Sealing and Identiﬁcation Label, and affixing the label sections to the sample bottle. f. Completing the Form
, Chain of Custody and Shipping Record. g. Packing the samples. h. Completing the shipping documents. (

) FCO/As unable to successfully complete a certiﬁcation requirement are ited from performing that task in the ﬁeld. They may perform other tasks for which they have been certiﬁed to perform. For example, an FCO/A who has been certiﬁed to sample fuel but has not been certiﬁed to ship fuel, may samples but may not ship the fuel. (
) The GM will provide the certiﬁcation status of each FCO/A to the Fuel TMs within

days of the most recent recertiﬁcation. The list will identify the most recent date of certiﬁcation. The TMs will send the list to the FC HCP coordina- tor annually. FCO/As not certiﬁed will also be identiﬁed. The list will identify the: • Date of certiﬁcation (most recent) • Duties an FCO/A is not certiﬁed to perform • The planned management actions to address an FCO/A’s certiﬁcation issues of State (
) A Fed-State Sampling Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) should be in place prior to training state employees dependent on the MOU. (
) The GM will coordinate with the state contact to provide the training. (

) The GM will provide an instructor for the initial training. This instructor will “state inspectors” and designated “state trainer(s)”. The state trainer(s) will train additional state inspectors, as well as additional “trainer(s)”, as needed. (

) The training of state employees is limited to the tasks the state employees perform. For example, if the state employees will not ship fuel samples, the employees will not be trained to ship products. (
) State training materials are available, when needed, upon request to Excise Tax Policy. (
) The IRS will provide support to the states as needed. Safety and Examination (

) The following are the minimum safety requirements: a. When conducting terminal inspections, FCO/As should ask the employee knowledgeable about the safety procedures and what their responsibili- ties are under the “Terminal’s Emergency Procedure Plan”; for instance, where to evacuate to, what is the recommended route, whom to report to, etc. At all other inspection sites, FCO/As should ask the employee charge about speciﬁc safety procedures in place. b. Always wear appropriate PPE. c. Do not ignite a ﬂame or smoke. d. Strong winds, dust storms, lightning, freezing rain, heavy snow and ﬂooding can interfere with safe climbing, screening and sampling opera- Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements

4.24.14.4.1(02-08-2016) Training of State Employees
When conducting terminal inspections, FCO/As should ask the employee knowledgeable about the safety procedures and what their responsibili

ties are under the “Terminal’s Emergency Procedure Plan”; for instance, where to evacuate to, what is the recommended route, whom to report to, etc. At all other inspection sites, FCO/As should ask the employee in charge about speciﬁc safety procedures in place. Always wear appropriate PPE. Do not ignite a ﬂame or smoke. Strong winds, dust storms, lightning, freezing rain, heavy snow and ﬂooding can interfere with safe climbing, screening and sampling opera
Strong winds, dust storms, lightning, freezing rain, heavy snow and ﬂooding can interfere with safe climbing, screening and sampling opera-

tions and make driving hazardous. FCO/As should not conduct screening and sampling during these types of weather conditions. e. Do not let fuel come into contact with any unprotected skin area. f. Avoid prolonged inhalation of fuel vapors. g. An FCO/A without Home-to-Work (HTW) authority must take special care to keep the personal vehicle used to travel to and from the parking location of the government vehicle free of fuel contaminates. If needed, he/she should change clothes at the end of the ﬁeld day and ensure their hands are clean. The soiled uniform should be bagged and cleaned pro- fessionally. See IRM

for information about professional cleaning services. h. Never enter conﬁned spaces such as trenches and storage tanks. Storage tanks that have a ﬂoating roof are considered a conﬁned space. i. Avoid any possibility of ingesting fuel. Do not eat, drink, or smoke in fuel sampling areas. Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after working around fuel. j. Do not use drugs or alcohol. k. Visually inspect a ladder prior to use. If the condition of the ladder appears unsafe, do not climb it. Always use three-point contact when climbing and descending ladders. Always face the ladder when ascending or descend- ing. Have one hand and both feet, or both hands and one foot in contact with the ladder at all times. l. When using gloves while climbing, always use the slip-resistant variety. m. Always check for ice, petroleum products, or other slick materials on ladders, catwalks, or other areas to be walked upon, including but not limited to, transport trucks, trailers, terminal racks, and driveways leading up to and away from racks and bulk storage tanks. n. Always check for overhead pipes or equipment while walking in a facility on top or around a transport. o. Always “bond”, to equalize any static electricity charge between the FCO/A, the container, and the fuel product. See IRM

below for more information. p. Always release the pressure in the transport compartments by opening hatch lid to the ﬁrst stop before opening the lid completely. q. FCO/As should never use electrical equipment in a terminal or any other facility/location where fuel is stored/dispensed. Physical examinations for FCO/As are conducted in accordance with the re- quirements found in
CFR Part
as referenced in IRM

, Human Resources Management, Medical Qualiﬁcation Determinations, Medical Qualiﬁ- cation Determination Requirements. The following criteria apply regarding physicals: a. The successful completion of a physical examination is required prior to entry on duty. b. The successful completion of a biennial physical examination is required to remain in the occupational ﬁeld. c. The physical examination is conducted by a Federal Occupational Health (FOH) physician or a physician contracted by FOH. d. A physical examination is offered when an FCO/A leaves the position.
Excise Tax

The successful completion of a physical examination is required prior to entry on duty. The successful completion of a biennial physical examination is required to remain in the occupational ﬁeld. The physical examination is conducted by a Federal Occupational Health (FOH) physician or a physician contracted by FOH. A physical examination is offered when an FCO/A leaves the position.
Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14 page
) Bonding Requirement Screening or Sampling Fuel (
) For the safety of the employees and to protect the safety and property of others, FCO/As must bond each time he or she screens or collects a sample of fuel. (

) Bonding equalizes the electrical charge (potential) between the ﬁeld person, the pipette/hand-pump, the container, and the fuel product. Note: The act of pumping taxable fuel across a rack into a transport tank compart- ment or rail car creates a strong electrostatic charge in the product. Employees are instructed to allow the load to “rest” for
minutes before collecting a sample. This resting period plus proper bonding allows safe sampling of the fuel. (
) Bonding must occur immediately prior to opening the tank. (
) Bonding is accomplished by bringing a bare hand and the equipment to be used (such as a pipette or sampling pump) into contact with the bare metal of the tank. (

) After bonding, it is important to minimize movement, especially your feet. If movement occurred such as leaving to talk to the driver or to obtain supplies, the bonding procedure must be followed again.
) Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) - Overview and Training (
) All PPE must meet OSHA Standards
CFR

The PPE items issued for use by FCO/As to mitigate occupational hazards are listed below: • Eye protection • Nitrile gloves • Safety helmet - hard hat • Flame resistant clothing • Safety shoes • High visibility safety vest • Portable ﬁre extinguishers • Spill kit • Waste oil container (
) All PPE training shall meet the requirements under OSHA Standards
CFR

(f). This paragraph describes training requirements for FCO/As who use PPE items that are issued by IRS to reduce or eliminate occupational injuries/illnesses while performing their job duties. a. Training shall be provided to every FCO/A who uses PPE. Training for each FCO/A will include an explanation of each PPE Item to be used,
For the safety of the employees and to protect the safety and property of others, FCO/As must bond each time he or she screens or collects a sample
Bonding equalizes the electrical charge (potential) between the ﬁeld person, the pipette/hand-pump, the container, and the fuel product.
All PPE must meet OSHA Standards 29 CFR 1910. The PPE items issued for use by FCO/As to mitigate occupational hazards are listed below:

• Nitrile gloves • Safety helmet - hard hat • Flame resistant clothing • Safety shoes • High visibility safety vest • Portable ﬁre extinguishers • Spill kit • Waste oil container All PPE training shall meet the requirements under OSHA Standards
CFR

(f). This paragraph describes training requirements for FCO/As who use PPE items that are issued by IRS to reduce or eliminate occupational injuries/illnesses while performing their job duties. a. Training shall be provided to every FCO/A who uses PPE. Training for each FCO/A will include an explanation of each PPE Item to be used, when use of a PPE item is necessary, how to properly ﬁt and wear each PPE item, limitations that may apply to PPE and proper care, mainte- nance, useful life and disposal of each PPE item. b. Each FCO/A shall demonstrate an understanding of the training and their ability to use each PPE item properly before the GM allows an FCO/A to perform their duties. c. Each FCO/A shall be retrained if they cannot demonstrate an understand- ing of the training and ability to use each PPE item properly. Retraining is required for changing conditions in the workplace or when previous training is rendered obsolete.

a. Training shall be provided to every FCO/A who uses PPE. Training for each FCO/A will include an explanation of each PPE Item to be used, when use of a PPE item is necessary, how to properly ﬁt and wear each PPE item, limitations that may apply to PPE and proper care, mainte

nance, useful life and disposal of each PPE item. b. Each FCO/A shall demonstrate an understanding of the training and their ability to use each PPE item properly before the GM allows an FCO/A to perform their duties. c. Each FCO/A shall be retrained if they cannot demonstrate an understand
ing of the training and ability to use each PPE item properly. Retraining is required for changing conditions in the workplace or when previous training is rendered obsolete.
IRS shall provide, at no cost to the FCO/A, all PPE items identiﬁed for use to perform their duties.
Note: All work uniforms provided by IRS for FCO/As are described under IRM 4.29.14.9, Required Uniforms.
Note: IRS is not responsible for purchasing everyday clothing for work, replacement of lost PPE items, or any PPE equipment that was intentionally damaged by the FCO/A.
intentionally damaged by the FCO/A. (

) All eye protectors, both the lenses and the frames, must be clearly labelled meeting the American National Standard Practice for Occupational and Educa- tional Eye and Face Protection Devices, American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Z
, Impact Standard, and protect from liquid or chemical splash. (

) FCO/As must wear eye protection while working with and around fuel. FCO/As may choose to use either safety glasses with side shields or safety goggles. Note: OSHA requires the use of safety goggles when working with fuel that is under pressure. (
) FCO/As who wear prescription lenses must wear ANSI approved eye protec- tors over the prescription lenses without disturbing the proper position of the prescription or the protective lenses. (
) Contact lenses ARE NOT a substitute for safe protective equipment for the eyes. Safety glasses with side shields or safety goggles must be worn over contact lenses. (
) Daily inspection and cleaning of the eye protection is recommended. Pitted dirty lenses may reduce vision. Replace eye protectors if the lenses are pitted or cannot be cleaned. (
) Nitrile gloves provide protection against skin contact with fuel products. The gloves must meet ANSI standard
, American National Standard for Hand Protection Selection Criteria. (
) Nitrile gloves are worn any time FCO/As may have contact with fuel products. (
) Gloves must be inspected before each use for pinholes and cracks. Do not wear jewelry that may puncture the gloves. (

) Except for single use gloves, nitrile gloves may be worn while climbing vehicle ladders. Note: For climbing vehicle ladders, FCO/As may also use leather gloves. The leather gloves may not be used when sampling or handling fuel. (
) The protective helmet, or hard hat, speciﬁed for use by FCO/As must meet ANSI Z
, American National Standard for Industrial Head Protection Protective Headgear for Industrial Workers Requirements. (
) The hard hat must be marked with certiﬁcation that it complies with that ANSI
(2) FCO/As must wear eye protection while working with and around fuel. FCO/As may choose to use either safety glasses with side shields or safety goggles.
Note: For climbing vehicle ladders, FCO/As may also use leather gloves. The leather gloves may not be used when sampling or handling fuel.
) The protective helmet, or hard hat, speciﬁed for use by FCO/As must meet the ANSI Z
, American National Standard for Industrial Head Protection Protective Headgear for Industrial Workers Requirements.
The hard hat must be marked with certiﬁcation that it complies with that ANSI
Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14 page
) The hard hat must have a hard outer shell and a shock-absorbing lining that incorporates a headband and straps that suspend the shell from
to

inches away from the head. The design provides shock absorption during impact and ventilation during normal wear. Prior to each use, the suspension should be checked for cracks and other defects. No stickers, logos, emblems, paint or other graphics may be placed on the hat since they may cover defects. (
) The hard hat must be worn when working in any area where there is a potential for injury to the head from falling objects. (

) The hard hat must be worn when working in any situation where the potential for injury to the head exists from FCO/As falling off an object. This includes, but is not limited to: a. Climbing a vehicle or tank. b. Working on top of the vehicle or tank. c. Any inspection site that safety regulations require headgear protection. (
) Flame resistant clothing is certiﬁed and rated verifying its adherence to safety standards. (
) It is designed to provide protection from ﬂash-burns and to enable the wearer a small amount of additional time to escape a ﬁre. (
) The clothing may be one-piece coveralls or consist of two pieces (top and pants). (

) The clothing must be worn at fuel terminals under the following conditions: a. During the tour of the terminal tank yard and distribution system. b. At the terminal rack. c. While obtaining a sample. d. While observing the terminal personnel obtain samples if the observation is conducted outdoors. (
) The clothing will also be worn when it is required by the safety policy of the facility being inspected. (
) FCO/As may elect to wear the clothing if they have safety concerns at other sites. (
) The ﬂame resistant clothing must be worn as the outer-most garment. Coats, jackets, and sweaters, if worn, are worn under the ﬂame resistant clothing. (

) Never sew, pin, or otherwise attach any item to the clothing. Doing any those actions to a ﬂame resistant garment compromises its resistance and wearer is not protected at the point the alteration was made. (
) The ﬂame resistant clothing should be washed and dried separately from clothing in accordance with the clothing manufacturer’s instructions. Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle

) The ﬂame resistant clothing must be visually inspected before each use. resistant clothing that becomes contaminated with grease or ﬂammable liquids must be cleaned in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions, prior to usage. (
) Safety shoes must always be worn by FCO/As as an integral part of the fuel compliance uniform. (
) To be approved for use by ﬁeld personnel, the safety shoes must meet the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) Standards F
, Test Methods for Foot Protection and F
, Speciﬁcation for Performance quirements for Foot Protection. (
) Approved safety shoes must have: • Slip-resistant soles. • A notched heel not to exceed
inch for safe climbing. • The heel must be resistant to punctures to protect the feet from sharp objects. (
) Approved safety shoes may not: • Be made of canvas material. • Have leather soles. Safety (

) The high visibility safety vest is an outer garment designed to make the more visible by standing out against the surroundings or background. Note: Do not wear the high visibility vest over ﬂame resistant clothing. The ﬂame resistant clothing will offer no protection for the parts of the body the vest covering. (
) The high visibility safety vest must meet ANSI/International Safety Equipment Association (ISEA)
, American National Standard for High Visibility Safety Apparel and Headwear. The high visibility safety vest must be Class orange or lime colored. (
) All FCO/As must wear the high visibility safety vest when working: • Around or near vehicular traffic. • Around or near moving equipment. • Within
feet of the edge of a traveled public highway. • On a construction site adjacent to the public highway. • In any other situation where safety is improved by increased visibility the workers. (

) Two portable ABC (it can be used on Class A, Class B or Class C ﬁres) ﬁre extinguishers are provided in each ﬂeet vehicle. The portable ﬁre extinguishers should be placed in both: • The cab of the vehicle • The vehicle bed

) Annually, each FCO/A is required to check the ﬁre extinguisher(s) in their assigned vehicle to ensure the extinguisher has not expired and is in working condition. Note: If the ﬁre extinguisher has expired, the FCO/A should dispose of the extin- guisher in accordance with local, state and federal regulations. (
) These units are designed for, and intended to, combat small ﬁres. (
) Use the “PASS” procedure: P - pull the pin or other seal, A - aim the nozzle at the base of the ﬁre, S - squeeze the lever, S - sweep from side to side. (
) FCO/As are supplied with an emergency spill kit or ﬁve pounds of absorbent clay used to clean up small spills of taxable fuels. (
) It is the responsibility of the FCO/A to make sure the spill kit is in the vehicle, intact, and quickly available. (
) FCO/As are required to wear eye protection while cleaning up a spill. (
) The absorbent sock (or pig) is used to contain or control a spill. A spill can contained or kept from migrating by proper placement of the absorbent sock. (
) The absorbent pad is used to absorb and wipe up the spill. (
) When ﬁnished cleaning up the spill, dispose of liquid and absorbent material waste in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. (
) Refer to
CFR Part
which contains all the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) regulations governing hazardous waste identiﬁcation, classiﬁcation, generation, management and disposal. (
) It is the GM’s responsibility to ensure that all FCO/As familiarize themselves with local and state hazardous waste program regulations. (
) Each vehicle is equipped with a waste oil container. (
) FCO/As will pour unneeded fuel samples and residual fuel from the sampling process into the container. (
) FCO/As are responsible for disposing of the fuel in accordance with local, and federal regulations. FCO/As should review all local, state and federal waste program regulations. (
) Refer to
CFR Part
which contains all RCRA regulations governing hazardous waste identiﬁcation, classiﬁcation, generation, management and disposal. (
) The fuel may not be used by FCO/As for any purpose. (
) FCO/As are supplied with free standing and/or magnetic designated inspection site signs and safety cones. (
) The designated inspection site signs are to be utilized when conducting in- spections at a designated inspection site. Internal Revenue Manual

) FCO/As are responsible for reporting all job-related injuries, no matter how slight, to the GM. This protects the employee’s rights under the Federal Employee Compensation Act (FECA). (
) For detailed information on reporting job-related injuries and worker’s compen- sation, see Document
, Employee Personnel Resource Guide. See the Publishing Repository for the latest version of this document. (
) Report any situation or incident that has caused or could cause harm to FCO/As or damage to IRS property. Some examples are theft, vandalism, threats to employees. See IRM
, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting, Incident Report. If the incident involves damage to the government vehicle, see IRM
Uniforms (

) The TM and GM are responsible for ensuring FCO/As are properly attired in the required uniform. During face-to-face interaction with an FCO/A, the GM will evaluate whether the uniform is being worn, as stipulated in this section. the uniform is not worn, as required, the FCO/A will be sent home and placed on leave. The GM does not have any discretion in this matter. (

) The required fuel compliance uniform consists of: • Navy blue headgear appropriate for the environment, with the official IRS patch secured. • Khaki colored shirt with collar with official IRS patch, American ﬂag patch, and name tag. • Navy blue trousers with belt. • Brown or black steel/composite toe boots. • Navy blue jacket/parka/windbreaker (seasonal) with official IRS patch, American ﬂag patch and name tag. Note: Clothing must be cotton or cotton blend for safety purposes. (
) FCO/As are provided with:

Navy blue headgear appropriate for the environment, with the official IRS patch secured. Khaki colored shirt with collar with official IRS patch, American ﬂag patch, and name tag. Navy blue trousers with belt. Brown or black steel/composite toe boots. Navy blue jacket/parka/windbreaker (seasonal) with official IRS patch, American ﬂag patch and name tag.
Note: Clothing must be cotton or cotton blend for safety purposes.

One windbreaker jacket. FCO’s ten and FCA’s ﬁve tan or khaki uniform shirts. Note: Short and long sleeve shirts are approved. FCO’s ten and FCA’s ﬁve navy blue cotton or cotton blend uniform pants One black or brown belt. One navy blue ball cap. One winter knit cap, if requested. One set of rain gear. Two pair of black or brown safety shoes. Name Tag.
Note: An FCO/A will always maintain one pair of shoes in the vehicle. Typically, this will be the older pair of shoes that still comply with safety standards.

• One winter-weight parka with a zip-out liner and detachable hood if the FCO/A works in an environment requiring winter clothing. (

) The fuel compliance uniform serves several purposes, it: a. Provides a nationwide standard professional appearance for IRS Fuel Compliance Field personnel. b. Enables FCO/As to be readily identiﬁed as an officer of the Federal Gov- ernment. c. Provides FCO/As some protection when working in environments contain- ing potential hazards. (

) FCO/As must wear the required uniform while they are in official duty status and/or when operating the government vehicle. The following lists exceptions, however, this list is not all inclusive; any other exception must be pre-approved by the GM. The exceptions are when: a. FCO/As expect to be engaged in administrative duties at a post of duty for the entire workday. b. FCO/As are working at home. c. FCO/As are traveling during the workday by private vehicle or commer- cial means to attend a meeting or training session. d. FCO/As are traveling to or attending a meeting or training session for entire workday. Note: The GM may require the uniform to be worn during a group meeting or training session if part of the purpose of the meeting is to enable the manager to inspect all FCO/A uniforms. e. FCO/As are in travel status after duty hours to obtain meals. f. FCAs are traveling to or from an examination or while conducting an ex- amination. FCAs are expected to wear professional attire typical of a revenue agent during contacts with the taxpayer and the public related the examination. (
) FCO/As are responsible to ensure the uniform is worn properly (i.e., shirt tail tucked in, buttons buttoned, etc.) and that all items are complete, clean, and good order. (
) Uniforms must be clean and professional in appearance. Professional cleaning services may be used. (
) The GM’s small purchase credit card is used to pay for the cleaner’s services. (
) Frayed, torn or stained uniforms must be replaced. (

) The Treasury seal patch is an integral part of the required uniform worn by all ﬁeld personnel. Each Treasury seal patch is an individually numbered and con- trolled item. The following procedures apply to the utilization of these controlled patches: a. FCO/As must sign a custody receipt to acknowledge receiving the patches. b. GMs and FCO/As are held accountable for the security of the patches. c. When clothing with the patch is not being worn, it must be secured. d. When in travel status, clothing with the patch is secured or shall remain in the possession of the traveler. Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle

) The name tag, in the format of ﬁrst initial, last name, is worn on the outermost garment above the breast pocket, if any, on the right-hand side of the chest. (

) FMSS Fleet Manager duties are delegated to staff in FMSS. The FMSS Fleet Manager is responsible for complying with the applicable regulations, directives and procedures that apply to the administration of the ﬂeet. (

) In addition, miscellaneous ﬂeet duties, such as administration of Home-to- Work, mileage reviews, and acquisition of aftermarket equipment are assigned to Excise Examination and Excise Tax Policy, which are outlined in the Memo- randum of Understanding (MOU) between Small Business/Self Employed (SBSE) and FMSS, effective October

) FCO/As are assigned a government vehicle to perform their duties. (
) FCO/As and GMs must comply with IRM

, as well as the applicable regulations, directives and procedures that contain information on the use government controlled vehicles and management responsibilities. Disciplinary measures are applicable if an FCO/A willfully misuses or authorizes the of the government vehicle. (
) For those FCO/As granted Home-to-Work authority, Treasury Directive

establishes the policy and sets forth responsibilities and reporting requirements concerning Home-to-Work use of the government vehicle. Annually, each employee with Home-to-Work authority must sign the Home-to-Work Certiﬁca- tion which certiﬁes the employee understands the restrictions on the use of vehicle, the potential disciplinary actions if the vehicle is used in an unauthor- ized manner, and that a Global Positioning System (GPS) tracking device is installed on the vehicle. The signed certiﬁcation must be provided to the A’s GM who will forward the signed forms to Excise Tax Policy, or as otherwise directed. Note: GMs do not have Home-to-Work authority.

FCO/As must comply with reporting requirements on the Mileage Log Page that include but are not limited to, maintaining:
(8) Flex fueled vehicles must be fueled with E85 unless exempt. See IRM 4.24.14.10.4 for more information on the use of E85.
) The GM must adhere to all requirements outlined in IRM
) The GM is accountable for all vehicles assigned to the group. The GM shall: a. Provide copies of IRM

and any subsequent updates, as necessary to FCOs and FCAs and have an acknowledged receipt of said convey- ance (i.e., e-mail). b. Ensure assigned vehicles are current with routine maintenance and repairs. c. Ensure FCO/As are aware of their responsibility regarding warranty sions. See IRM

d. Alert the FMSS Fleet Manager of any signiﬁcant vehicle issues. e. Obtain supplies, services, and accessory equipment for the vehicles assigned to the group. f. Report the theft of an assigned vehicle to the FMSS Fleet Manager within

hours. g. Maintain a record of the license plates for the vehicles assigned to the group and ensure lost, stolen or mutilated license plates are reported the FMSS Fleet Manager. The list of license plates shall include the stolen, destroyed and voided plate numbers. h. Conduct regular reviews to ensure each employee uses the government vehicle in an authorized manner and adheres to the record keeping re- quirements. i. Ensure all FCO/As take the mandatory training as deﬁned in IRM

j. Obtain signed Home-to-Work Certiﬁcations annually from all FCO/As who have been granted Home-to-Work authority. The certiﬁcation form should be signed following the completion of the annual Excise FCO/FCA Fleet Vehicle training. (

) The GM will send vehicle reassignment requests to the FMSS Fleet Manager. The request must identify the: • Vehicle(s) VIN(s) involved. • Field personnel involved. • Reason for the reassignment. • Proposed effective date. Note: The FMSS Fleet Manager will decide whether to approve the request and will inform the GM of the decision. If the vehicle will be reassigned, the FMSS Fleet Manager will inform General Services Administration (GSA) Excise Tax Policy.

) The GM will perform periodic mileage log reviews to ensure completeness and accuracy of the log and to identify any unauthorized use. The reviews shall be documented on the Mileage Log Review - Managers (site) which is a link on the FCO/A Employee Mileage Log Page. There are two types of reviews: standard and comprehensive. The standard review will be conducted monthly. During the standard review the GM shall, at a minimum: a. Ensure the mileage log is completed timely, as required by IRM

below. b. Ensure the ending odometer reading for each day increases compared the preceding day and the miles driven each day is reasonable given the destination(s) recorded on the log. c. Ensure receipts are properly uploaded and documented appropriately. d. Ensure E

is documented when purchased and when not purchased receipt and log are documented as to why it was not purchased. e. Ensure purchase receipts match the amounts recorded in the log. f. Ensure commuting trips are documented properly and were an authorized use of the vehicle (information on the activity performed at the post of duty should be recorded in the log). g. Ensure any use outside the tour of duty is documented properly and was an authorized use of the vehicle (information on the activity performed outside the tour of duty should be recorded in the log). (

) If the standard review identiﬁes potential discrepancies or errors, the GM should document accordingly and notify the FCO/A. A comprehensive review may be warranted to further investigate and resolve the discrepancies. If unre- solved issues or indications of misuse are determined, the GM manager must document accordingly and notify the TM. (

) A comprehensive review of mileage logs will be conducted twice a year on each FCO/A to identify unauthorized use. Each review will consist of a thorough review of a two-month period (a total of four months for each employee). The GM should analyze records such as time sheets, the work planner, ﬂeet card purchases, IMS records, and the reports generated by the GPS tracking device to: a. Compare the destinations in the work planner to the destinations listed the mileage log. b. Determine the business purpose for each day the vehicle is used. c. Identify any potential personal usage. d. Ensure that the vehicle was not used during days the FCO/A was on leave or working all day at the post of duty or ﬂexi-place location. e. Determine whether the fuel consumption and miles per gallon are rea- sonable for the work performed. f. Ensure that FCAs are using the government vehicle for inspection related duties. See IRM
below. Note: The two-month period reviewed should be expanded to include additional months if potential inappropriate or unauthorized use is identiﬁed. (

) The GM shall maintain a record of each comprehensive review on the Share- Point mileage log. The record shall detail the actions taken and the results of the review. The GM will upload documentation to corroborate the ﬁndings of the review.

) If the information provided by the FCP/A is not complete or there are discrep- ancies, then the GM must contact the FCO/A for correction or clariﬁcation. there are indications of inappropriate or unauthorized use, then the GM must contact the TM for guidance on how to proceed. (

) The FCO/A must maintain a valid driver’s license to operate the government vehicle and must notify the GM promptly if the FCO/A’s license is suspended, revoked, or expired. (
) FCO/As will self-certify on the Shar
oint mileage log in the comments annually that they have a valid driver’s license. See IRM
for more mation about licensing. The self-certiﬁcation should occur during the month January. (
) The FCO/A is responsible for completing the training as described in IRM
, Defensive Driving Training Requirements, and inform the GM when it is complete. These training courses cover the vehicle operator’s re- sponsibility to safely operate a government vehicle. (
) The FCO/A is responsible for completing the Excise FCO/FCA Fleet Vehicle training, annually. (
) The FCO/A must wear the official uniform while operating the assigned See IRM
for exceptions. (
) The FCO/A must use the Shar

oint Mileage log to record use of the govern- ment vehicle as well as commuting trips and use of the vehicle outside the employee’s tour of duty. No other means of recordation may be submitted mileage log. The log must: a. Identify the name and title of the person assigned the vehicle. b. Identify the GM authorizing the use of the vehicle. c. Record the date of use. d. Record starting location and ending location. e. Record destination. Note: Record the counties in which inspections or other duties were performed. f. Record the purpose of vehicle use. g. Record the daily ending odometer reading. h. Record commuting use and reason for such use. i. Record any use outside the FCO/A’s tour of duty hours and reason for such use. j. Include uploaded IRS maintenance and gas purchase receipt(s). k. Record the use of the ﬂeet credit card. This includes the cost of the fuel, gallons purchased, whether E
was purchased, and the cost and tion of other ﬂeet card purchases. Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle

) The Shar
oint mileage log must be updated at least every two weeks in cordance with Single Entry Time Reporting (SETR), timekeeping cycles. (
) FCO/As will be required to submit their mileage log for the ﬁnal month of the accounting year within ﬁve calendar days of the end of November. The ac- counting year runs from December
st through November
th. (
) The FCO/A must report lost, stolen, or mutilated license plates to the GM local police. The written report to the GM must explain the circumstances regarding the lost, stolen, or mutilated plate. (
) The FCO/A must contact the GM if a required vehicle service or repair is not covered by warranty or a service plan. (

) FCAs may only use the government vehicle for travel related to fuel inspection duties and vehicle maintenance. FCAs shall not use the vehicle for travel related to examinations or other non-inspection related duties. (

) If an FCA plans to perform both examination and fuel inspection duties during the same workday or during an overnight temporary duty trip, the government vehicle may be used if such use promotes the efficiency and economy of the government. FCAs should contact the GM if unsure whether use of the vehicle is authorized. (

) Use of the government vehicle is required when obtaining and transporting and fuel sampling supplies. There is no circumstance in which an FCA’s or FCO’s private vehicle may be used for these functions. Card (
) The FCO/A must use a ﬂeet services credit card for fuel and maintenance services. (
) The ﬂeet services credit card is assigned speciﬁcally to each vehicle and should be used only for the vehicle identiﬁed on the card. (
) For answers to questions regarding fuel, maintenance and repair of the GSA vehicle refer to IRM
, Treasury Directive

, and the Guide to your GSA Fleet Vehicle, which was provided with the vehicle at the time it was assigned to the FCO/A. The guide contains answers to questions about the dollar limits and procedures for obtaining goods and services. The guide may also be found under, Important Fleet Publications at the GSA website address: GSA - Fleet Portal . (

) When purchasing fuel at the pump, the FCO/A will be prompted to input the current odometer reading along with the Personal Identiﬁcation Number (PIN), currently the numeric portion of the vehicle license plate. For billing and main- tenance purposes, it is important an accurate odometer reading is entered. Note: If the fuel receipt does not identify the location of fuel purchase, the FCO/A should notate the address on the fuel receipt.

) FCO/As should follow IRM
requirements for information pertaining to vehicle maintenance and repairs. Questions regarding purchases, maintenance and repairs of vehicles should be directed to the FMSS Fleet Manager. (
) The operator is responsible to ensure the vehicle is properly maintained. (
) If the vehicle is still within the manufacturer’s warranty period, it should be taken to the nearest authorized dealer for the make of vehicle for repair at no cost to the federal government. (
) Since warranty repairs are made at no cost to the government for parts and labor, expenditures for repairs during the warranty period must be approved the FMSS Fleet Manager. (

) The items and services that may be purchased and how much may be spent determined by GSA. Questions about the limits and procedures for obtaining goods and services should be directed to the FMSS Fleet Manager. (
) When there is a signiﬁcant change in miles per gallon of fuel used by a vehicle, the vehicle should be evaluated to determine the cause. (
) Vehicles within the fuel compliance ﬂeet operate on conventional gasoline or are alternative fuel vehicles and can operate on either conventional gasoline E
E
is an abbreviation for an ethanol fuel blend of up to
percent denatured ethanol fuel and
percent gasoline or other hydrocarbon (HC) by volume. E
is commonly used by ﬂex-fuel vehicles in the US. (
) Section
, Energy Policy Act (EPAct) of

requires that all federal ﬂeet dual-fuel vehicles must operate on alternative fuel rather than conventional petroleum, unless one of the two conditions below is satisﬁed: a. The alternative fuel was not available. Availability is deﬁned as alternative fuel available within ﬁve miles or a ﬁfteen-minute drive from where the vehicle is garaged. b. The alternative fuel is more expensive per gallon than gasoline. (
) The FMSS Fleet Manager will notify the GM if any of the vehicles are granted a waiver. (

) All federal ﬂeet dual-fuel vehicles must operate on alternative fuel if it is readily available in their geographic area unless there is insufficient fuel remaining in the propulsion tank to reach the nearest E
station. (
) The FCO/A shall maintain a list of the E
fueling stations within their assigned territory. An updated list can be obtained at Alternative Fuels Data Center - Al- ternative Fueling Station Locators . (
) If the driver fueled with E
and the receipt does not identify the fuel as E
, the FCO/A shall record “E
” on the receipt. Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle

) U.S. Government license plates shall be displayed on all assigned vehicles. The plate must be displayed on the vehicle to which it was assigned. Plates may not be transferred to another vehicle. (
) The vehicles are equipped with license plates that display the following required information: • For Official Use Only • U.S. Government (
) The license plate shall be displayed on the front and rear in the normal for a license plate on that model of vehicle. (
) No part of the license plate may be obstructed by license plate brackets, surrounds, etc. (
) When the vehicle is turned in, the license plate will remain with the vehicle. (
) The FMSS Fleet Manager will review the written report from the GM regarding lost, stolen or mutilated license plates. (

Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14 page
Below is a list of equipment/supplies that should always be in the assigned vehicle.

Item Fire extinguisher with an ABC class rating, placed in cab of vehicle Fire extinguisher with an ABC class rating, in vehicle bed-accessible Safety helmet (hard hat) Safety glasses with side shields or goggles that meets the ANSI standard Flame resistant coveralls or two-piece set, as well as the laundering guide for ﬂame retardant clothing Extra complete uniform to include a shirt, pants and shoes Nitrile gloves Steel or composite toe safety shoes, if not worn, must be available in vehicle Eye wash kit (check to ensure eye wash kit has not expired) Spill kit or 5 lbs. of absorbent clay (kitty litter) First aid kit (check to ensure ﬁrst aid kit supplies have not expired) Battery operated warning/ﬂashing lights, in cab of vehicle Life Hammer, in cab of vehicle Orange safety cones with reﬂector stripes Orange or lime high visibility safety vest Hand Cleaner Sampling pump Clear plastic tubing, may be Tygon brand 30-inch pipettes 60-inch pipettes Disposable, single-use funnels, may be plastic or paper Clear glass 2 ﬂ. oz. sample bottles Black caps with plastic seals for above Plastic funnel Porcelain/metal 5-gallon pail or bucket Clear glass measuring cup or large wide-mouth glass jar Absorbent wipes/paper towels (one pack or one roll) Diesel can (diesel can must be labeled)

Item Carrying case/plastic tote to hold supplies Magnetic fuel inspection site sign or freestanding fuel inspection site sign Flashlight and batteries Ice scraper with brush attachment Hazardous waste can (one to ﬁve gallon) Trash bags for waste can Current edition of Fuel Compliance IRM Sections 4.24.13, 4.24.14, 4.24.15 and 4.24.16 IRM 1.14.7, Motor Vehicle Management (current edition) GSA Vehicle Packet, “Guide to your GSA Vehicle” CA-1 Incident Report SF 91 Motor Vehicle Accident Report SDS for unleaded regular gasoline SDS for unleaded premium gasoline SDS for number 2 diesel fuel (one each for LSD and ULSD) SDS for number 2 dyed diesel fuel SDS for Jet A SDS for number 1 kerosene SDS for dyed kerosene Hazmat Training Certiﬁcate Pub 1, Your Rights as a Taxpayer Notice 916 (EN/SP), Taxable Fuel Inspection Notice Publication 4941, Truckers Bulletin, both English and Spanish versions Form 9667, Sample Bottle Sealing and Identiﬁcation Labels Form 12180, Third Party Contact Form Form 13926, Chain of Custody Control Document Form 13927, Chain of Custody and Shipping Record Form 4564, Information Document Request Letter 3918, Fuel Inspection Letter Form 3210, Document Transmittal Form 637, Application for Registration Form 3244-A, Payment Posting Voucher Exhibit 4.24.14-1 Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No. 54956X (05-02-2022)
Excise Fuel Compliance Safety, Uniform, and Motor Vehicle Requirements 4.24.14 page
Exhibit 4.24.14-1 (Cont. 2) (02-08-2016) Mandatory Vehicle Equipment List
Item Form 8849, Claim for Refund of Excise Taxes
Step
- FMSS or GM notiﬁes FCO/A the truck will be turned in.
Step
- FCO/A lists the contents, usable items and quantities. The list of most likely property will be found in IRM
Step
A- GM shares the list with group and solicits interest. GM will instruct FCO/A to send supplies and equipment to speciﬁc employees. The FCO/A will update the list as items are requested.
Step
B- GM expands solicitation to territory and other excise territory. GM will instruct FCO/A to send supplies and equipment to speciﬁc employees. The FCO/A will update the list as items are requested.
Step
- FCO/A separates the consumable and non-consumable items. See the list below titled Examples of Consumable Items.
Step
- GM makes reasonable efforts to retain the consumable items. Recommend group and TM secretaries consider items on-hand before ordering supplies.
Step
- FCO/A emails FMSS-HQ Property to arrange disposal of property. Provide the list to FMSS Property & Asset Management HQ.
Step
- FCO/A coordinates with FMSS to excess or dispose of the items. The options will depend the FCO/A locale, type of property and other factors.
Goals of the Process: • Ensure the IRS adheres to Federal Management Regulations and IRM
guidance for the disposal of government property declared excess.
Ensure the IRS adheres to Federal Management Regulations and IRM 1.14.4 guidance for the disposal of government property declared excess.

Exhibit 4.24.14-2 (Cont. 1) (05-02-2022) Steps to Excess and Dispose Fuel Sampling Equipment and Supplies
Establish uniform process for disposing of unneeded equipment and supplies. Promote efficient use of government resources.

Establish uniform process for disposing of unneeded • Promote efficient use of government resources. Examples of Consumable Items • Nitrile gloves • Pipettes • Tubing and funnels • Garmin GPS unit • Sample bottles and caps • Shipping boxes for fuel samples • Form
Sample bottle labels • Sample pumps • Hand cleaner, paper towels, hand wipes trash bags • First aid kits
